message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests leukocyte adhesion deficiency syndrome (LAD). Among the options, only absence of CD18 molecule on the surface of leukocytes is a characteristic of LAD. The other options are associated with other types of primary immunodeficiency syndromes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recurring skin infections and history of otitis media suggest a primary immunodeficiency. The inflamed and red skin around the mouth is most likely angular cheilitis, which is commonly associated with a deficiency in the CD18 molecule on the surface of leukocytes. Defects in tyrosine kinase, IL-12 receptor deficiency, and deficiency in NADPH oxidase are associated with other types of primary immunodeficiencies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recurring skin infections and otitis media suggest an immunodeficiency disorder. Option C is correct as the absence of the CD18 molecule on the surface of leukocytes is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency, which can cause recurrent infections of the skin, respiratory, and urinary tracts. The other options are associated with different immunodeficiency conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Recurring skin infections and otitis media suggest immunodeficiency. Among the options, only absence of CD18 molecule on the surface of leukocytes is associated with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections. Delayed umbilical cord separation may also suggest a possible diagnosis of leukocyte adhesion deficiency syndrome, which is associated with absence of CD18 molecule. The inflamed and red skin around the mouth is a possible sign of a bacterial infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD), which is caused by a deficiency in the CD18 molecule on the surface of leukocytes. Defect in tyrosine kinase causes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, IL-12 receptor deficiency causes Mendelian susceptibility to mycobacterial diseases, and deficiency in NADPH oxidase causes chronic granulomatous disease, all of which have different clinical presentations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recurring skin infections suggest an immune deficiency disorder, and among the options, only absent CD18 molecules on the surface of leukocytes leads to Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD), which increases the risk of infections. The inflamed and red skin around the mouth is a result of poor wound healing. Defects in tyrosine kinase, IL-12 receptor deficiency, and deficiency in NADPH oxidase lead to SCID, Chronic Granulomatous Disease, and X-linked chronic granulomatous disease, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s recurring skin infections, especially around the mouth, suggest a deficiency in CD18 molecule on the surface of leukocytes. This deficiency causes Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD1) which results in impaired activation and migration of leukocytes. Defects in tyrosine kinase (Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome), IL-12 receptor (immunodeficiency with interleukin-12 receptor blockade), and NADPH oxidase (chronic granulomatous disease) can also cause immunodeficiency, but their symptoms and presentations are different from LAD1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Recurring skin infections and otitis media suggest a possible immunodeficiency disorder. Absence of CD18 molecule on the surface of leukocytes is characteristic of Leukocyte adhesion deficiency, which leads to recurrent skin and mucosal infections. The other options are not related to this disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation of recurring skin infections and a history of otitis media suggests immunodeficiency. Among the options, only absence of CD18 molecule on the surface of leukocytes is consistent with leukocyte adhesion deficiency, which can result in impaired immune system function and recurrent infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recurring skin infections and otitis media suggest an immunodeficiency disorder. CD18 molecule deficiency is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency, which causes recurrent bacterial infections and delayed umbilical cord separation. Inflamed and red skin around the mouth suggests a local skin infection, which can occur as a result of immunodeficiency.
